decision.reasoning:
The market has Seahawks at 58.7%, which implies they‚Äôre a fairly clear favorite. From the available stats, I don‚Äôt see enough separation to justify that big an edge.

What moves me toward Patriots value:
- New England‚Äôs offense created explosive plays at a league-best 13.6% rate (per ESPN snippet). That‚Äôs the kind of efficiency that can swing a single game even if the baseline offense is inconsistent.
- The Patriots‚Äô playoff path included very low-scoring wins (e.g., 16-3 WC; 10-7 in the AFC title game per PFR snippets), which is consistent with a defense/variance profile that keeps games close‚Äîuseful when betting as an underdog.
- The Ringer note about Maye having a high tight-window throw rate (17.3%) indicates volatility (turnover/negative-play risk), but volatility cuts both ways: it lowers their ‚Äúmedian‚Äù outcome but increases upset chances, which is exactly what an underdog bet wants.

What keeps me from going all-in:
- Seattle‚Äôs explosive-play differential being best in the NFL (4.7 pp) suggests they are legitimately strong and not just ‚Äúlucky,‚Äù and they‚Äôre described as the best pass offense the Patriots have faced in the playoffs.

Net: I‚Äôd price Seattle more like ~52‚Äì55% rather than 58.7%. That makes NO at 41.3% meaningfully +EV, so I‚Äôm taking a moderate position consistent with risk limits.
